FILE: cm091200v11.0.txt
DYAD: HONDURAS - UNITED KINGDOM
RIVALRY: RIV222
DISPUTE(S): MID1734 

Territorial-Maritime-Boundary Issues Variables

MID1734 

TERRMID: MID1734 3 -- not territory
TERRMID-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain 
TERRMID-NOTES: 

TERRLINK: MID1734 3 -- not third party link to territory 
TERRLINK-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain
TERRLINK-NOTES: 

MARITMID: MID1734 3 -- not maritime 
MARITMID-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain
MARITMID-NOTES: 

ISLMID: MID1734 3 -- not islands 
ISLMID-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain
ISLMID-NOTES: 

CIVWARMID: MID1734 1 -- civil war MID
CIVWARMID-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain
CIVWARMID-NOTES: MID1734 on 2/6/1911, the New York Times reported that Honduras was experiencing civil conflict as a group of revolutionaries was fighting against the government. From Gibler, Miller, and Little (2016), the US and UK intervened by trying to help prevent rebels from taking the capital of Honduras. Coded civil war MID because a revolution in Honduras led to the US and UK intervening in order to end the conflict, triggering this MID. 

CIVWARLINK: MID1734 3 -- not civil war link
CIVWARLINK-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain
CIVWARLINK-NOTES: 

COUPMID: MID1734 1 -- coup MID
COUPMID-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain 
COUPMID-NOTES: MID1734 the revolutionaries in Honduras were being led by General Bonilla. Coded coup MID because a Honduran military elite was attempting to overthrow the government of Honduras. 

COUPLINK: MID1734 3 -- not coup link
COUPLINK-CER: MID1734 1 -- certain 
COUPLINK-NOTES: 

RIVNOTES: 

NARRATIVE-CM:

SOURCES-CM:

NARRATIVE-CR:

SOURCES-CR:
New York Times 2/6/1911
D. M. Gibler, S. V. Miller, and E. K. Little. 2016. "An Analysis of the Militarized Interstate Dispute (MID) Dataset, 1816-2001." International Studies Quarterly. 60 (4): 719-730.
